qas.question: What happened in the European Union in 1996?

answers.text: agreed to a number of exceptions for young people in its child labour laws

qas.question: What age were children allowed to do light labour?
What age were children able to take part in European training programs?
What is the most common occupation for Dutch youth to have?

context: Similarly, in 1996, member countries of the European Union, per Directive 94/33/EC, <a0_0>agreed to a number of exceptions for young people in its child labour laws<a0_0/>. Under these rules, children of various ages may work in cultural, artistic, sporting or advertising activities if authorised by the competent authority. Children above the age of <a1_0>13<a1_0/> may perform light work for a limited number of hours per week in other economic activities as defined at the discretion of each country. Additionally, the European law exception allows children <a2_0>aged 14 years or over<a2_0/> to work as part of a work/training scheme. The EU Directive clarified that these exceptions do not allow child labour where the children may experience harmful exposure to dangerous substances. Nonetheless, many children under the age of 13 do work, even in the most developed countries of the EU. For instance, a recent study showed over a third of Dutch twelve-year-old kids had a job, the most common being <a3_0>babysitting<a3_0/>.
